com.googlecode.objectify
Interface Objectify

All Known Implementing Classes:
ObjectifyImpl
public interface Objectify

This interface is similar to DatastoreService, except that instead of working with Entity you work with real typed objects.

Unlike DatastoreService, none of these methods take a Transaction as a parameter. Instead, a transaction (or lack thereof) is associated with a particular instance of this interface when you create it.

Author:
Jeff Schnitzer

Method Detail

get

<T> java.util.Map<Key<T>,T> get(java.lang.Iterable<? extends Key<? extends T>> keys)
Performs a batch get, returning your typed objects. Yes, the generic syntax is crazy, but it means you can pass in a list of OKeys.

Parameters:
keys - are the keys to fetch; you can mix and match the types of objects.
Returns:
a empty map if no keys are found in the datastore.
See Also:
DatastoreService.get(Iterable)

get

<T> T get(Key<? extends T> key)
      throws com.google.appengine.api.datastore.EntityNotFoundException
Gets one instance of your typed object.

Throws:
com.google.appengine.api.datastore.EntityNotFoundException - if the key does not exist in the datastore
See Also:
DatastoreService.get(Key)

get

<T> T get(java.lang.Class<? extends T> clazz,
          long id)
      throws com.google.appengine.api.datastore.EntityNotFoundException
This is a convenience method, shorthand for get(ObjectifyFactory.createKey(clazz, id));

Throws:
com.google.appengine.api.datastore.EntityNotFoundException - if the key does not exist in the datastore

get

<T> T get(java.lang.Class<? extends T> clazz,
          java.lang.String name)
      throws com.google.appengine.api.datastore.EntityNotFoundException
This is a convenience method, shorthand for get(ObjectifyFactory.createKey(clazz, name));

Throws:
com.google.appengine.api.datastore.EntityNotFoundException - if the key does not exist in the datastore

get

<T> java.util.Map<Key<T>,T> get(java.lang.Class<? extends T> clazz,
                                java.lang.Iterable<?> idsOrNames)
This is a convenience method that prevents you from having to assemble all the Keys yourself and calling get(Iterable). Note that unlike that method, this method only deletes a homogeneous set of objects.

Parameters:
idsOrNames - must be of type Iterable (which translates to id keys) or of type Iterable (which translates to name keys).
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if ids is not Iterable or Iterable

find

<T> T find(Key<? extends T> key)
Identical to get(Key) but returns null instead of throwing EntityNotFoundException

find

<T> T find(java.lang.Class<? extends T> clazz,
           long id)
Identical to get(Class, long) but returns null instead of throwing EntityNotFoundException

find

<T> T find(java.lang.Class<? extends T> clazz,
           java.lang.String name)
Identical to get(Class, name) but returns null instead of throwing EntityNotFoundException

put

<T> Key<T> put(T obj)
Just like the DatastoreService method, but uses your typed object. If the object has a null key, one will be created. If the object has a key, it will overwrite any value formerly stored with that key.

See Also:
DatastoreService.put(com.google.appengine.api.datastore.Entity)

put

<T> java.util.List<Key<T>> put(java.lang.Iterable<? extends T> objs)
Just like the DatastoreService method, but uses your typed objects. If any of the objects have a null key, one will be created. If any of the objects has a key, it will overwrite any value formerly stored with that key. You can mix and match the types of objects stored.

See Also:
DatastoreService.put(Iterable)

delete

void delete(java.lang.Object keyOrEntity)
Deletes the specified entity. The object passed in can be either a Key or an entity object; if an entity, only the id fields are relevant.

delete

void delete(java.lang.Iterable<?> keysOrEntities)
Deletes the specified keys or entities. If the parameter is an iterable of entity objects, only their key fields are relevant.

Parameters:
keysOrEntities - can be either an iterable of Key objects or an iterable of entity objects. They can even be mixed and matched. The result will be one batch delete.
See Also:
DatastoreService.delete(Iterable)

query

<T> Query<T> query()

Create a typesafe query across all kinds of entities.

query

<T> Query<T> query(java.lang.Class<T> clazz)

Create a typesafe query across one specific kind of entity.

getTxn

com.google.appengine.api.datastore.Transaction getTxn()

Note that this is *not* the same as DatastoreService.getCurrentTransaction(), which uses implicit transaction management. Objectify does not use implicit (thread local) transactions.

Returns:
the transaction associated with this Objectify instance, or null if no transaction is associated with this instance.

getDatastore

com.google.appengine.api.datastore.DatastoreService getDatastore()
Returns:
the underlying DatastoreService implementation so you can work with Entity objects if you so choose. Also allows you to allocateIds or examine thread local transactions.
